I think this is usually investigated under the name of Complex
Evolutionary Systems.

Some genetic-based simulations do not use that same "generation" cycle
we usually have in GAs. Individuals may reproduce with some
probability when they "meet" and have enough energy to do so. Also,
the population can increase/decrease arbitrarily. Individuals die when
their energy is below a certain threshold so there's not "direct"
selection mechanism.

I've been thinking how that would work with a population of
ANN-controlled organisms living in a 2D environment and borrowing some
ideas from NEAT, like the genetic encoding method and the crossover
and mutation operators.

There were some approaches like these in the past (before NEAT) but
most of them don't highlight the differences between the standard GA
and such complex system simulation.

I know this message has little to do with picbreeder, but Petar's
points motivated to write :-)

Cesar

> As I wrote that answer, I started thinking on how to create unguided
>  evolution in computers based on the principles of NEAT. This is a
>  very complex problem. The problem is not that every GA is evolving to
>  a predefined target and easily skips promising genomes. The problem
>  is the difference between the GAs and nature. In nature, there is no
>  somebody like God who says "You're good and you deserve to mate, and
>  you will die". The organisms are choosing their mates. So, a very
>  good genome will not survive just because its phenotype can eat a lot
>  or live longer.. In fact, the phenotypes themselves tell which is
>  good, very indirectly. This kind of indirection need to be
>  abstracted. If we want to achieve a lot of complexity that was never
>  discovered by humans, we have to give the individuals the power of...
>  Say, it's like democracy in human society.
>  What I see in Picbreeder and IEC at all, is that the human takes the
>  role of each indivudual, when he sees one. As I run my view through
>  these 15 images, for each one I am thinking of the image as it was
>  me. I say "I'm looking fine!", or "Oh, I'm so ugly!".
>  So, the way to automate this kind of process is to find a way to let
>  the individuals express themselves. The human designer sets up the
>  environment, of course, but everything else should happen
>  automatically. The selection method must be very very different than
>  the usual, I guess.
>  How we can put this into something practical? I have some
>  suggestions, but it turns out to be a kind of Alife stuff. Well, I
>  cannot even express myself! :)
>  Does somebody have any ideas?
>
>  Peter
